column1: # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE MANUALLY. IT WAS GENERATED BY ETL step 'explorers/migration/2024-08-05/refugees_asylum_migration'.

column2: Explore the migration of people across the world.

column3: Number of [internally displaced children](#dod:internally-displaced) under 18 years old, displaced due to conflict and violence. This includes all internally displaced children in this country and should not be confused with children who got displaced in this year.
column4: Internally displaced children due to conflict and violence

column3: Number of [internally displaced children](#dod:internally-displaced) under 18 years old, displaced due to disasters. This includes all internally displaced children in this country and should not be confused with children who got displaced in this year.
column4: Internally displaced children due to disasters

column3: Total number of [internally displaced children](#dod:internally-displaced) under 18 years old. This includes all internally displaced children in this country and should not be confused with children who got displaced in this year.

Number of children under 18 years old who are international [immigrants](#dod:immigrant) by the country of destination. This number is the total migrant stock, so all migrants who are currently living in the destination country, and does not describe migrants arriving in this year.
column4: Immigrants under 18 years old by destination

column3: [Internal displacements](#dod:internally-displaced) of children under 18 years old, during this calendar year due to conflict and violence. Displacements describe the movement of one child from their place of residence to another place within the same country due to conflict and violence.
column4: New internal displacements of children due to conflict

column3: [Internal displacements](#dod:internally-displaced) of children under 18 years old, during this calendar year due to disasters. Displacements describe the movement of one child from their place of residence to another place within the same country due to natural disaster.
column4: New internal displacements of children due to disasters

column3: Total number of [internal displacements](#dod:internally-displaced) of children under 18 years old, during this calendar year. Displacements describe the movement of one child, which has to leave their place of residence, to another place within the same country.

Number of children under 18 years old who are [refugees](#dod:refugee) by the country of asylum. This number is the total refugee stock, so all refugees who are currently living in the asylum country and does not describe refugees arriving in this year.
column4: Child refugees by country of asylum

column3: Number of children under 18 years old who are [refugees](#dod:refugee) by their country of origin. This number is the total refugee stock, so all refugees who have left the origin country and does not describe refugees leaving in this year.
column4: Child refugees by country of origin

column3: Number of children under 18 years old who are [refugees](#dod:refugee) per 1000 inhabitants of the asylum country. This number is the total refugee stock, so all refugees who are currently living in the asylum country and does not describe refugees arriving in this year.
column4: Child refugees per 1000 inhabitants of the country of asylum
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column3: Number of children under 18 years old who are [refugees](#dod:refugee) per 1000 inhabitants of the origin country. This number is the total refugee stock, so all refugees who have left the origin country and does not describe refugees leaving in this year.
column4: Child refugees per 1000 inhabitants of the country of origin
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column3: Number of children under 18 years old who are international [immigrants](#dod:immigrant) per 1000 inhabitants of the destination country. This number is the total migrant stock, so all migrants who are currently living in the destination country, and does not describe migrants arriving in this year.
column4: Immigrants under 18 years old by destination per 1000 inhabitants
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column3: Number of [internally displaced children](#dod:internally-displaced) under 18 years old per 1000 inhabitants of the country. This includes all internally displaced children in this country and should not be confused with children who got displaced in this year.
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column3: Number of new [internally displacements](#dod:internally-displaced) of children under 18 years old per 1000 inhabitants of the country. Displacements describe the movement of one child, which has to leave their place of residence, to another place within the same country.
column4: New internal displacements of children per 1000 inhabitants
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column6: Our World in Data, based on UNICEF (2021)

column3: Number of new [internal displacements](#dod:internally-displaced) of children under 18 years old due to conflict and violence per 1000 inhabitants of the country. Displacements describe the movement of one child, which has to leave their place of residence, to another place within the same country due to conflict and violence.

Displacements describe the movement of one child, which has to leave their place of residence, to another place within the same country due to natural disaster.

column3: Number of [refugees](#dod:refugee) in all regions by the country of origin. This measures the total number of refugees from the country; not the number per year.
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [asylum seekers](#dod:asylumseeker) in all regions by the country of origin. This measures the total number of asylum seekers from the country; not the number per year.
column4: Asylum seekers by country of origin
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [refugees](#dod:refugee) under UNHCR's mandate in all regions by the country they live in. This measures the total number of refugees; not the number per year.
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [asylum seekers](#dod:asylumseeker) in all regions by the country they seek asylum in. This measures the total number of asylum-seekers; not the number per year.
column4: Asylum seekers by country of residence
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of returned [refugees](#dod:refugee) by the country of origin and return. Only refugees who returned during the calendar year are included.
column4: Returned refugees by country of origin
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of newly [resettled refugees](#dod:resettlement) by the country of origin, which is the country the refugee originally fled from. Resettlement enables refugees to relocate to another country which has agreed to admit them with a legal status ensuring international protection and ultimately permanent residence.
column4: Resettlement arrivals by country of origin
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of returned [refugees](#dod:refugee) by the country they lived in before their return. Only refugees who returned during the calendar year are included.
column4: Returned refugees by country they returned from
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Newly [resettled refugees](#dod:resettlement) by the country they resettle in. Resettlement enables refugees to relocate to another country which has agreed to admit them with a legal status ensuring international protection and ultimately permanent residence.
column4: Resettlement arrivals by country of resettlement
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [refugees](#dod:refugee) by country of origin, per 1,000 people in that country. This measures the total number of refugees from the country; not the number per year.
column4: Refugees by country of origin per 1,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [refugees](#dod:refugee) by country of asylum, per 1,000 people in that country.
column4: Refugees by country of asylum per 1,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [asylum seekers](#dod:asylumseeker) per 100,000 people in the country of origin. This measures the total number of asylum seekers from the country; not the number per year.
column4: Asylum seekers by country of origin per 100,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Number of [asylum seekers](#dod:asylumseeker) by country of residence, per 100,000 people in that country.
column4: Asylum seekers by country of residence per 100,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Newly [resettled refugees](#dod:resettlement) by country of origin, per 100,000 people living in the country of origin. Resettlement enables refugees to relocate to another country which has agreed to admit them with a legal status ensuring international protection and ultimately permanent residence.
column4: Resettlement arrivals by country of origin per 100,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: Newly [resettled refugees](#dod:resettlement) in this country, per 100,000 people living in the country of settlement. Resettlement enables refugees to relocate to another country which has agreed to admit them with a legal status ensuring international protection and ultimately permanent residence.
column4: Resettlement arrivals by country of resettlement per 100,000 people
column6: Our World in Data, based on UNHCR (2024)

column3: The total number of people living in a given country who were born in another country.
column6: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: Total number of immigrants as a share of the total population.
column4: Share of the population that were born in another country
column6: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The total number of people who have left the country
column6: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The change in the total number of migrants living in a given country compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more migrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column4: Change in the number of international immigrants in the previous five years
column6: Our World in Data, based on United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The total number of people born in that country that are now living in another country, compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more emigrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column4: Change in the number of emigrants in the previous five years
column6: Our World in Data, based on United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The change in the total number of migrants living in a given country compared to five years ago, per 1,000 people in the host country. A positive number indicates there are now more migrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column4: Change in the number of international migrants per 1,000 people in the previous five years
column6: Our World in Data, based on United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The total number of people born in that country that are now living in another country, compared to five years ago, per 1,000 people in the host country. A positive number indicates there are now more emigrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column4: Change in the number of emigrants per 1,000 people in the previous five years
column6: Our World in Data, based on United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The total number of people that have left the country, as a share of the current population.
column4: Share of the population that have left the country
column6: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (2020)

column3: The total number of [immigrants](#dod:immigrant) (people moving into a given country) minus the number of [emigrants](#dod:emigrant) (people moving out of the country).

The total number of [immigrants](#dod:immigrant) (people moving into a given country) minus the number of [emigrants](#dod:emigrant) (people moving out of the country), per 1,000 people in the population.
Share of GDP that is made up of the sum of all personal [remittances](#dod:remittances) sent by migrants to their home countries.

The average [transaction cost](#dod:remittancecost) as a percentage of total [remittance](#dod:remittances) sent from abroad to this country and includes exchange rate margin, fees, and other charges. The cost of sending remittances is based on a single transaction of USD 200.
column4: Average transaction cost of sending remittances to a specific country (%)

column3: The average [transaction cost](#dod:remittancecost) as a percentage of total [remittance](#dod:remittances) received from abroad and includes exchange rate margin, fees, and other charges. The cost of sending remittances is based on a single transaction of USD 200.
column4: Average transaction cost of sending remittances from a specific country (%)

column3: [Internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) due to conflict. This includes all people who are currently displaced due to conflict and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.
column4: Internally displaced people due to conflict

column3: Internal displacement describes the movement of a person who is forced to leave their home due to conflict but who remains within their country's borders.
Internal displacement describes the movement of a person who is forced to leave their home but who remains within their country's borders.

[Internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) due to natural disasters. This includes all people who are currently displaced due to disasters and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.
column4: Internally displaced people due to disaster

column3: [Internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) due to both conflict and violence and natural disaster. This includes all people who are currently displaced and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.

Internal displacements due to both conflict and violence and natural disaster. Internal displacement describes the movement of a person who is forced to leave their home but who remains within their country's borders.

The share of [internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) of all people living in the country. This includes all people who are currently displaced and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.
column4: Share of internally displaced people of total population
column6: Our World in Data, based on Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (2024)

column3: The share of [internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) due to conflict of all people living in the country. This includes all people who are currently displaced due to conflict and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.
column4: Share of internally displaced people due to conflict of total population
column6: Our World in Data, based on Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (2024)

column3: The share of [internally displaced people](#dod:internally-displaced) due to disaster of all people living in the country. This includes all people who are currently displaced due to disasters and should not be confused with people who got displaced in this year.
column4: Share of internally displaced people due to disaster of total population
column6: Our World in Data, based on Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (2024)

column3: The number of internal displacements due to both conflict and disaster, per 100 people living in the country. Internal displacement describes the movement of a person who is forced to leave their home but who remains within their country's borders.
